a: Elements in which the last electron enters the $(n-1)d$ subshell. They are in Groups 3-12.
Defined as elements which have an **incompletely filled $d$-orbital** in their ground state or in any one of their common oxidation states.
They have a completely filled \( (n-1)d^{10} \) configuration in their ground state and in their common \( +2 \) oxidation state. They are $d$-block, but not T.M.s.
\( [Ar] 3d^5 4s^1 \) (Not $3d^4 4s^2$). This is due to the extra stability of the **half-filled** $d^5$ subshell.
\( [Ar] 3d^{10} 4s^1 \) (Not $3d^9 4s^2$). This is due to the extra stability of the **fully-filled** $d^{10}$ subshell.

Decreases from $\text{Sc} \to 	ext{Cr}$ (increasing $\text{Z}_{eff}$), remains almost constant $\text{Cr} 	o 	ext{Cu}$ ($	ext{Z}_{eff}$ balanced by shielding), increases at $\text{Zn}$ (e-e repulsion in $d^{10}$).
Very high for T.M.s due to strong metallic bonding (involving unpaired $d$-electrons). Peaks mid-series (e.g., $\text{V}, \text{Cr}$) where unpaired $e^-$ are maximum.
Very high, peak mid-series (e.g., $\text{Cr}$ has max m.p. in 3d) due to strong metallic bonds from unpaired $d$-electrons. $\text{Mn}$ and $\text{Tc}$ have anomalous dips.
Increases across the series, but irregularly. $\text{IE}_1$ of $d$-block is between $s$-block and $p$-block.
The third IE ($\text{IE}_3$) for $	ext{Mn}$ is exceptionally high. This is because the $e^-$ must be removed from the stable $3d^5$ (half-filled) configuration of $	ext{Mn}^{2+}$.
The third IE ($\text{IE}_3$) for $	ext{Zn}$ is also exceptionally high, as it involves removing an $e^-$ from the very stable $3d^{10}$ configuration of $	ext{Zn}^{2+}$.
Due to the small energy difference between \( (n-1)d \) and \( ns \) orbitals. Both can be used for bonding. Highest O.S. is $\text{Mn} (+7)$ in $	ext{MnO}_4^-$.
Both are very stable as they have the $d^5$ (half-filled) configuration.
$	ext{Sc}^{3+}$ is stable (noble gas $d^0$ config). $	ext{Zn}^{2+}$ is stable (pseudo-noble gas $d^{10}$ config).
Generally become less negative (more 'noble') across the series. $\text{Mn}$, $\text{Ni}$, $\text{Zn}$ have more negative $E^\circ$ values than expected.
The high energy needed for $\Delta H_{\text{atom}} + (\text{IE}_1 + \text{IE}_2)$ is **not** compensated by the hydration enthalpy ($\Delta H_{\text{hyd}}$).
The reduction $	ext{Mn}^{3+} \to 	ext{Mn}^{2+}$ is highly favourable because the product $	ext{Mn}^{2+}$ has a very stable $d^5$ (half-filled) configuration.
\( \mu = \sqrt{n(n+2)} \ \text{B.M.} \) (Bohr Magnetons), where $\text{n}$ = number of unpaired electrons.
$3d^6$ has 4 unpaired electrons ($n=4$). $\mu = \sqrt{4(4+2)} = \sqrt{24} \approx 4.90 \ \text{B.M.}$

q: Cause of Colour in T.M. ions
a: Due to $\mathbf{d-d}$ **electron transitions**. Unpaired $d$-electrons absorb energy from visible light to jump to a higher-energy $d$-orbital. The observed colour is the complementary colour.
They have no unpaired $d$-electrons (or have empty/full $d$-orbitals). $d-d$ transitions are not possible.
Colour is due to **Ligand to Metal Charge Transfer (LMCT)**, not $d-d$ transition. An $e^-$ from $	ext{O}^{2-}$ jumps to $	ext{Mn}^{7+}$.
1. High m.p. (higher than parent metal). 2. Very hard (e.g., steel, tungsten carbide). 3. Retain metallic conductivity. 4. Chemically inert.
T.M.s have similar atomic radii, allowing atoms of one metal to easily substitute atoms of another in the crystal lattice. E.g., Brass ($	ext{Cu/Zn}$), Bronze ($	ext{Cu/Sn}$).

\( 2\text{CrO}_4^{2-} \text{(Yellow)} + 2\text{H}^+ \rightleftharpoons \text{Cr}_2\text{O}_7^{2-} \text{(Orange)} + \text{H}_2\text{O} \) (Dichromate stable in $\text{acidic}$, Chromate stable in $\text{basic}$ medium.)
\( 4\text{FeCr}_2\text{O}_4 + 8\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 + 7\text{O}_2 \xrightarrow{\text{Fusion}} 8\text{Na}_2\text{CrO}_4 + 2\text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3 + 8\text{CO}_2 \)
Two tetrahedral $\text{CrO}_4$ units sharing one oxygen atom. $\text{Cr}-\text{O}-\text{Cr}$ bond angle is $\approx 126^\circ$.
\( \text{Cr}_2\text{O}_7^{2-} + 14\text{H}^+ + 6\text{Fe}^{2+} \to 2\text{Cr}^{3+} + 6\text{Fe}^{3+} + 7\text{H}_2\text{O} \)
\( 2\text{MnO}_2 + 4\text{KOH} + \text{O}_2 \xrightarrow{\text{Fusion}} 2\text{K}_2\text{MnO}_4 + 2\text{H}_2\text{O} \) (Forms Green Manganate ion $\text{MnO}_4^{2-}$)
Disproportionation in acidic/neutral solution: \( 3\text{MnO}_4^{2-} + 4\text{H}^+ \to 2\text{MnO}_4^{-} + \text{MnO}_2 + 2\text{H}_2\text{O} \) (Purple $	ext{MnO}_4^{-}$)
\( \text{MnO}_4^{-} + 8\text{H}^+ + 5e^- \to \text{Mn}^{2+} + 4\text{H}_2\text{O} \) ($E^\circ = +1.51V$)
\( 2\text{MnO}_4^{-} + 5\text{C}_2\text{O}_4^{2-} + 16\text{H}^+ \to 2\text{Mn}^{2+} + 10\text{CO}_2 + 8\text{H}_2\text{O} \)
\( \text{MnO}_4^{-} + 2\text{H}_2\text{O} + 3e^- \to \text{MnO}_2 + 4\text{OH}^- \) (Forms $	ext{MnO}_2$ precipitate)

q: O.S. change of $\text{Mn}$ in $\text{KMnO}_4$ in Acidic, Neutral, and Basic media?
a: Acidic: $\text{Mn}^{+7} \to \text{Mn}^{+2}$ (5 electrons). \( \text{Neutral/Weakly Basic: } \text{Mn}^{+7} \to \text{Mn}^{+4} \) (3 electrons). \( \text{Strongly Basic: } \text{Mn}^{+7} \to \text{Mn}^{+6} \) (1 electron).
The steady, gradual decrease in atomic and ionic radii (\( \text{Ln}^{3+} \)) across the Lanthanoid series (from $\text{Ce}$ to $\text{Lu}$).
Due to the **poor shielding effect** of the $4f$ electrons. As nuclear charge increases, the $4f$ orbitals fail to shield the outer $6s$ electrons effectively.

The radii of the $4d$ and $5d$ transition series elements are almost identical (e.g., $\text{Zr} \approx \text{Hf}$, $\text{Nb} \approx \text{Ta}$). This makes their chemical separation very difficult.

q: Consequence 2 of L.C.: Basicity of Hydroxides
a: Basicity of $\text{Ln}(	ext{OH})_3$ decreases from $\text{La}(	ext{OH})_3$ to $	ext{Lu}(	ext{OH})_3$ due to decreasing ionic size and increasing covalent character.
\( +3 \) is the most common and stable O.S. for all Lanthanoids.
Occur when they lead to a stable $f^0$ (e.g., $\text{Ce}^{4+}$), $f^7$ (e.g., $\text{Eu}^{2+}$, $	ext{Tb}^{4+}$), or $f^{14}$ (e.g., $\text{Yb}^{2+}$) configuration.
An important alloy of Lanthanoids ($\approx 95\%$) and $	ext{Fe}$ ($\approx 5\%$) + traces of S, C, Ca, Al. Used in lighter flints.

q: Why do Actinoids show a greater range of O.S.?
a: Due to the very small energy gap between the $5f, 6d,$ and $7s$ orbitals, allowing all to participate in bonding. (e.g., $	ext{Np}$ and $	ext{Pu}$ can show up to $+7$ O.S.)
$5f$ orbitals have even **poorer shielding** than $4f$ orbitals, leading to a stronger 'Actinoid Contraction' across the series.
Actinoids are far more reactive (e.g., with acids, $\text{H}_2\text{O}$) than Lanthanoids, especially in finely divided form. All Actinoids are radioactive.
